commentBody: 10 minutes in and nothing makes sense. So, I check the Wordplay column.

Phew! I managed to catch on to the trick pretty quickly and ended up racing through this puzzle, but it definitely required more brainpower and focus to get the job done. 

A great use of the creative freedom offered by Thursday!
Interesting wrinkle! Thanks.
Wow. Impressed. Started with an extreme lack of progress at first. Got scared. Great puzzle.
The most clever Thursday I’ve seen in a while.  Speedy solve once the trick makes sense.  Kudos to Jesse Goldberg.  Well played.

A cute theme, which was fun to solve.

But once the theme clicked (thanks to the revealer clue), filling in most of the Down answers was nigh-automatic, so the puzzle did not put up much resistance.

Also, some of the clues seemed unnecessarily strange. SETI is not a subject; it's an organization. I don't think OGLE is related to greediness.
Ehhhhhhh. Cute, I guess. More tedious than clever.
This puzzle gives me math anxiety

Commenting without reading the wordplay blog yet because this looks like a mess.  Then I get to this:

52A “What each down answer needs from its clue in order to make sense.”

What?! Like what the jiminy cricket is happening here?

Okay, will be back after solving the puzzle and reading the blog.

Didn't want to cut the stone tablet without checking crosses, so when I was sure of 1A, 14A, 17A and 20A but the downs were missing something, I noticed what 52A confirmed. Now if only all the Down entries had also been words without 52A.

Nice [if easy] Thursday, Jesse!
Ok, that was totally maddening and then totally fun! I love a puzzle that stimulates some unused corner of my brain and delivers a genuinely euphoric eureka moment. Bravo!

Hated it until I loved it.

I had 3 letter rebuses all along the tops until I realized the trick. Extremely clever and impressive construction.
meh - candidate for worst puzzle of the year
Way too easy once you get the gimmick, since you start every clue with the first two letters. 2D was a gimme, so I figured out the gimmick immediately
Nice.
Stunningly impressive. Fun!
I was disappointed to find out that the SeaWolves didn't permanently change their name to the Moon Mammoths, and are only doing it for four games.

Ok, I saw that there was something missing at the top of the downs before getting to the revealer, but it eluded me for a good while because I stubbornly tried to find some way to have a three letter rebus in the first down square or two two letter rebuses in the top two down squares.  When that proved futile I hit on the idea of just skipping the first two letters, and things fell into place fairly quickly after that.  But the at the end I had a mistake (scuse instead of SCUSI) and had to track that down. I found the puzzle clever, challenging, and an interesting change of pace, but not my favorite.

I'm still not sure how I feel about it. Very frustrating at first. Saw the revealer clue and was like... How? I can't solve the downs to try to get a hint at the revealer without the revealer? ALL the down clues don't make sense without doing something to them?

Eventually I was able to get a down answer filled with crosses, the revealer clicked, and the rest was less than 10 minutes.

Was the frustration at the beginning worth the payoff? Usually I'm an easy "yes, it was." but I'm unsure on this one.
Duh. I did this whole puzzle before I realized that each clue contained the missing letters. I guess I was lucky the cluing was easy.

It didn't take too long to figure out that not only the first row, but all downs were missing their first two letters. However, being my occasionally oblivious self, I didn't notice that those first two letters were borrowed from the clue until the revealer. The solve really sped up after that, and I came in well under my average.

Fun puzzle that exercised some different pathways in my brain. Thanks!
The cleverest crossword I've seen in a long time, and so unexpected for a Thursday!
Hated it until I read the blog and figured out the trick. I wish I had noticed it while solving! In retrospect very impressive.
Very clever. I liked it. Something completely different!

Sorry for the shameless gloating but I completed a 1000 streak today and am feeling super thrilled about it - and I couldn't have asked for a better puzzle to hit this number. 

I genuinely look forward to the NYT crossword's release each day and am very grateful to this puzzle for keeping me sane especially during the early COVID years. I also owe a lot to the community here - even though I don't post that often, I always read the comments and often learn something new or insightful or at least get a chuckle out of it that makes my day and for that I'm very, very grateful.
Loved loved loved this one. So much fun. Great puzzle.
Eh - very easy once you figure out the gimmick and at the end you end up with a mess of a grid. Not my favorite.

Wow, that was amazing! I read the revealer clue when wandering around the grid. Got to “Stop’s opposite”, looked at the clue again and after grinning, entered (ST)ART. Then thought “seriously?” All the downs? Let’s see… and couldn’t stop till done. Felt like a maniac. Fast, but enjoyable.
Took me a while to see trIPLEA… 26D… just phonetic AAA.
I suffered through the whole puzzle without realizing the clues were feeding us the letters 😭😭 Now I have a headache
Didn't the Seawolves recently become the Moon Mammoths?

Commenting again after reading the other comments - I can’t believe people didn’t enjoy this! Different puzzles for different folks, I guess. I found the trick quick and easy to pick up, so it was a very quick solve for a Thursday, and yet so very satisfying. Thank you constructor and editors, really brightened up my day!

[“Favorite Thursday puzzle of the year”]

BULOUS

It took me until the last two down clues for STRIDE and BESTED before I realized the trick. What a marvelous aha moment it was.

Well done, Jesse!

P.S. For non-Americans, TRIPLE A (26D) stands for Automobile Association of America.
That was fun! Tickled the brain a bit filling in the gaps while remembering the first letters. Had to use the rebus a couple of times just to keep track. I enjoyed it.

That might be the fastest I’ve ever figured out the Thursday gimmick.  FANT in the SW corner triggered it, thankfully, or I still might be suffering through it!

Fun puzzle!

Now THIS is a Thursday. 
How the hell did I figure this in out?
And how the hell do you construct a puzzle like this?
I beat my average, but during my first look through I thought it would take ages.
Bravo to Jesse Goldberg!

Very odd/frustrating and then very smooth. And I think some commenters are really going to hate it! LoL But not me - I ultimately found it fun and impressive that EVERY down answer followed the same formula. Wow! 

I knew PETER and SCUSI were correct, but those downs were looking really weird. Then somehow APP STORE struck me and I thought maybe AP was the running link? 

Finally PARISHES and RETURF gave me the pattern. But I initially thought it would just be the top row, not the entire puzzle. Just wow!

As I sometimes do, I started this puzzle by going through all the DOWN clues. Well, I got nothing in that first pass, but it did seem that a lot of the obvious answers were longer than the available space.
Very entertaining!

loved it!

there is that feeling of struggle and doubt and then everything clicks into place ~ that is the fun of this puzzle

happy thursday, everyone!
That was very cool. I always look forward to Thursdays and Sundays. And not just during football season.
I just finished the puzzle but what kind of chaos did I just participate in?
Loved it. Lots of fun! To me, it was like using the Spelling Bee Buddy hints to get to Queen Bee. 😁🐝

Scattershot to start but once I got inFANT the clouds cleared. 

As I did the puzzle, I especially enjoyed the cluing (since the down clues were doubly helpful). 

It’s a good reminder of how constraints (fixing the first two letters of each clue) can lead to creative solutions.

I personally enjoyed this. There weren’t too many absolute gimmes on the downs to clue me in to two letters missing, nor enough gimmes on the acrosses to make it obvious right away. Sure I wondered why ANGELS didn’t fit but I figured I was missing a less obvious team. Really didn’t figure it out until I read the revealer, discovered something was up with all the Down answers, got OBAMA and said HELMET had to fit, saw the HE in the clue, filled in FIRSTTWOLETTERS, and then it was an easy themeless with the first two letters of each down clue.

I can’t wait to read the comments. I won’t rag on you if you didn’t like it. I know there are purists who don’t believe in nonsense entries and we have a whole grid of them. You may feel that this was more of an exercise for the constructor than the solver, which is reasonable especially since once you get the trick it’s pretty easy. My biggest disappointment was reading the constructor’s notes—I give points for creativity and difficulty, but if Jesse really stuck existing clues into a computer program and then picked a grid he liked, that’s a major downer for me (no pun intended). I know that’s still not an inconsequential feat at all, but I would love to have heard how he painstaking devised original clues and threw some out because they didn’t work, etc.

Still, bottom line I enjoyed the puzzle and solving it so that’s still a thumbs up from me, and it was a clever idea and thought experiment.

Great puzzle. Frustrating as heck at first as I didn’t get enough across clues to figure out the trick. Came here to the comment section and learned that two free letters are being handed to me! Then it became one of the easier Thursday puzzles but a lot of fun!
Horrible...Never realized the "trick" until I read WordPlay.
I hated this ... until I didn't. Great puzzle.
Oh boy. How cute. Maybe tomorrow a crossword puzzle?
I solved it but it looked to me like a construction stunt and not a very interesting one. A small bit of interesting trivia, not much wordplay. But that's just my opinion.

FInally a puzzle worthy of Thursday. The revealer showed us the trick that was there all along, with no awkward cluing, and little fill that was too esoteric.

9.5/10.
Today’s puzzle provides the latest answer to that burning question:  What will they think of next?

I kind of wish the puzzle had been inverted so that the Across answers were the ones missing the first two letters.  As probably most people do, I go through the clues in order starting with the Acrosses, so I got to the revealer without having tried any of the Downs, which spoiled some of the fun.

Sometimes, it helps to skip clues until you come across the clue that begins to reveal the theme.
Noticed something was amiss at 2D, proceeded down to 52A for an aha moment.
Thereafter, smooth sailing as clues were not Thursday level.

Cute but feel like I've only had half a portion.
Impressive! “Infant” was my breakthrough though it still took a bit of trial and error to get the theme. Grew up in Chicago so Threepeat was an easy one. Kudos!

I was absolutely engrossed in this superb puzzle.  

That is, after I got the idea I was engrossed.  Before that I was lost, lost, lost.  Lost.

Really hilarious, especially as I put all three letters into the down clues as rebuses, only to have to rip them out when I didn't get the glory page.

A real banger of a puzzle--one of my favorites ever.

I can hardly wait for the first complaint about how "something something down" cannot possible be "something".

👇








Actually, I'm not really looking forward to complaints of that type.  I'm actually dreading it.
Down answers need to all be real words or phrases as written (just not the right answers to their clues) for this to work.
I can live with the theme (maybe even enjoy it), but calling SETI a subj. is just a bridge too far.

Wow. Literally the worst crossword I’ve ever done. I usually don’t do Thursday, crossword puzzles, so I had no clue that there would actually be letters missing from the answers to the clues. This has to be spelled out somewhere beyond a really hard clue later in the puzzle, in order for somebody to be able to get it. Unless this  just for people who have been doing crosswords for years, which kind of defeats the point of crosswords being there to test your brain instead of being through rote familiarization
Anyone else get DOOKed by [TR]IP LEA? 😂 (26 down). What’s a “trip lea”? Is that like a trip planner?

I got a wordplay problem. 

I knew from the first three downs that something nutty was going on. Game on, constrictor. 
Figured out the trick pretty quickly before I got to the revealer. 

I was amazed at the novelty and what I assume is crazy hard constructing to pull this off. 

BUT.  While I’m having fun filling out the downs. (I wasn’t interested in across clue anymore).  I keep thinking.  What is wordplay content gonna be like.  “Those guys better not pan this puzzle. Or I’m gonna lose it”.  I’m having fun typing in answers, but hate-reading in my mind. 

I haven’t looked at comments yet. But man I hope wrong. All I know is that 1:45 after puzzle drop, there are 90 comments. That seems like a lot?  Oh oh.  If you can’t find joy in this grid. You need to stop doing Thursdays. 


I was dismayed a bit at the constructor notes though.  The process for creating this puzzle seemed like a piece of cake, based on how I interpreted the notes. I hope I’m wrong. Or maybe, I hope I’m right. Because if all you need is an idea, and it’s so easy to create the grid. Then me and Jesse got some collabing to do.  

This is why I love Thursday. Nonsensical madness, until it isn’t.  Madness every down clue.  Yes please!  Thank you Jesse.

Solved it perfectly using 3 letter rebus capability with the first two letters  added in for the down clues and not shared by the across,   this seems perfectly in tune with the revealer, but was disallowed as a solution.

A good challenging puzzle with unfair scoring.  Tell me how I'm wrong...

Wow, Jesse Goldberg, just wow!
What a mind you have, what a brain! 

Truly astounding.

Thank you for this work of art.
Bravo!

Cute puzzle, i guess.  I got the revealed easily enough.  Unfortunately, while the trick was obvious, the design felt random.  If the letters in puzzle had all spelled out real words, it would have been a real mindbender.  Even after reading the WordPlay blog, I had to go back to each of the down clues to see the pattern.  When I solve a puzzle and have to reread the clues and study the puzzle to figure out the pattern, it feels more tedious than fun.

On another note, I agree with those who have issue with the clue for SETI. It seems like a misfire.
Super clever!!

My first response after going through the puzzle with almost nothing to show for it was, Not interested.  IPASS.  But it turned out to be an ingenious challenge that was not at all difficult once I had some questionable across fills and got  to the revealer.  Then it was just flat out fun and I had a wonderful time!

Thank you, Jesse, it was a delight.  Come back soon (but please don't scare me like that again)..

As usual I peeked down for a revealer and once I saw the clue I thought I'd never figure it out, but after plugging away for a few minutes I got the trick. A smooth solve. I always love the Aha moment of a good tricky puzzle!

This one's gonna have some haters though, guaranteed.
Anyone else figure out that the first two letters of down words were missing but not that those letters started the clues?

If you have your “Thursday brain” equipped, I’d say it’s not too bad. It was a quick solve once I figured out the wrinkle with a few of the more obvious down clues. If I wasn’t looking for highjinks, I could see being stumped/frustrated.

I think the joy of a puzzle like this, whether one calls it a crossword puzzle or a "crossword puzzle", is that you are quickly presented with a challenge that goes beyond word skill, into pattern solving (or problem solving?) skill.

Like everyone else I was baffled at how badly things were going, and of course it being a Thursday you're looking for a trick pitch. 

But now the actually answers to the clues become secondary to figuring out the trick--you're pretty sure that unless you understand that trick you probably won't be able to solve the puzzle.  At all.

Suddenly parts of the brain that were asleep are hurried into duty, to help the parts of the brain that work with ordinary crossword skills.

It's all cells on deck.

It's really rewarding when it works out.  And it's maddening when it doesn't.  But it makes it a lot more likely you'll get the next one.

When I realized that IMPALA didn't fit, I felt very smart for thinking of NYALA, only to be humbled by the secret third 5-letter-long African antelope with an A in the third position. Who named these creatures? I just want to talk.
I hate puzzles like this. It really takes the fun out of it.
Not fun, makes it painful and a slog rather than an enjoyable experience.

ive only been addicted to the times crosswords for nine months or so but heres what i loved about this puzzle:  whether you love or hate rebi and word splitting/sandwiching/doohickying, anagrams and the fifty other types of word frippery that appear on thursdays, here is the first such puzzle ive encountered whose solution entirely hinges on the trick.
no prospect of working around or ignoring the trick in order to solve by crosses.
all in.
totally rad.
more of these, please.
SeaWolves? You mean the Moon Mammoths!

STESSES  was entered out of desperation and  the penny dropped. I was having a fairly miserable time of it until then. 

After that it was dominos falling which was very pleasing. 

A worthy thematic Thursday. 

I remained baffled by IPLEA until I read the comments here. 

Thanks to the constructor and the editors.

One you read the revealer clue, you may figure that the strategy is to solve enough nearby accrosses to get just one down answer to help solve the pattern.

From there this was maybe the easiest Thursday I've seen.since each down answer came with the first 2 letters for free.

I liked this, other than crossing a defunct shoe polish brand with a specific antelope species.

Good one though.

This was even worse than using rebuses, because as annoying as those are, at least you can cross-check answers. Here, you just have to guess that you have things right. This isn't a puzzle, it's a dartboard, and we're all playing blindfolded. So silly.

First thoughts: What the heck is going on? It can't be a rebus, as nothing makes sense. What other tricks have I seen… Hmm, letters off the grid? Maybe, but that doesn't work for the downs lower in the puzzle.

(Later…) Wait a minute… what's this clue for 52A? And what's the answer—AHA!

Neat trick, and I haven't seen it before, so definitely Thursday worthy for me. I don't care that the down answers in the grid aren't complete words. It was a good head-scratcher for a while, and then it was pretty easy to finish after after seeing the revealer.

Nice one, Jesse, you got me good for a while!

I like challenging puzzles but this is ridiculous.  Rebuses are hard enough.  Leaving out occasional letters are very difficult.  But leaving off letters on all down clues more than triples the usual solve time, even after the pattern is discovered.
This is one of those gimmicky puzzles that's probably much more fun for the developer than for the user.

That was a neat trick. The across entries were easy enough to provide me with enough letters for the downs to figure out what was going on very quickly. The fill was mercifully quite light on arcane trivia. The result? A solve in Tuesday/Wednesday time without lookups. Actually, I found this easier than both Tuesday and Wednesday this week.

I have a feeling I have seen THREEPEAT in these puzzles before, but of course I didn't remember what it was. Once I got it from crosses I looked it up. Winning three championships in a row. Ok, that makes sense. We don't have a word for it in Polish - we handle it descriptively.

The most confusing entry of the whole puzzle for me was TRIPLEA (another solution I got from crosses only). I could not parse it, at all. What on Earth is a triplea, I though. Is it a brand? Of course it's not covered by the column so I googled it. Oh, TRIPLE A! However, the first dozen or so answers in Google are about AAA the game engine. Now I seem to recall AAA being an American roadside assistance thing or some such?

I also don't get "Scratch and save" solving to SCRIMP. Any help? I don't understand what the word means and thus also how it relates to its clue.

Lucyfer the puppy's breeder sent us pictures of his grandfather. Wow. That's one huge poodle! My wife and I like big dogs so we're hoping Lucek inherited that beast's size genes 🤣.

So... saying to "borrow the first two letters from each Down clue and add them to the beginning" just means... removing them? I might be missing something, or else that's just a little needlessly confusingly worded.

Otherwise, meh – the conceit is fine, but would feel more purposeful to me if each Down answer solved to a new word instead of just becoming gibberish after its first two letters are removed.
Tricky but fun to finally figure out.

Things I was finally able to do after starting this fantastic puzzle in the middle of the night:

RAIGHTEN UP and stop thinking rebus
RUG IT OFF
RIDE along filling in downs 
keep my REAK alive

I loved this puzzle.  Confusing, as it should be, but fun and mentally challenging (I’m not a fast speller any more).  A lot of real “spelling it out”.
 • 
But as soon as I got to replace on the mound, I put in LIEVE, without knowing why.  But it fit.
 • 
Thanks, 👋🏽.
Ugh.

I SPED through this once I figured out the gimmick.
Others will probably not enjoy it as much. To each their own.

M
M
I
C
K

Give it time, it’s easy once you see it…

(To be clear, I quite liked it!)

Puzzle Creator, I hope you are pleased with yourself.  I’m angered enough by this crossword that I felt the need to comment.  There are so many Thursday puzzles that are challenging and interesting, and it’s a shame I can’t include this one in that list.  I’d say “Try again,” but I’m not interested in another puzzle from you.  I don’t worry about solve times or other nonsense.  I just want a decent challenge, not a solution that asks me to omit the first two letters of my answer, revealing gibberish for each down answer.  Perhaps you could do better, but I’m unwilling to find out.

I did not realise until *after* I had completed it and read this blog that the first two letters of the down clues are the first two letters of the down answers 🤦🏻‍♀️ I did the whole thing guessing what the words could be without knowing the first two letters.
Awesome puzzle! Great example of why I love Thursdays!

LOVED this puzzle! The Aha moment was really a treat, as was going back and solving clues that had seemed unsolvable moments before. 

I assumed there would be rebuses involved, but I couldn't find any pattern.... until I got to the big revealer. 

Very nicely done! Perfect Thursday!
10D's clue should be "Possible," not "Possibility." And for that reason, I'm out.
I liked it. I can see where others wouldn't but I did. And yes, had a brief moment where I thought there were rebuses.

"Did you read the book about milk?"
"I just skimmed it."

("You couldn't read the whole thing? It was condensed!")

This one almost did me in 😅 I knew 2D was (AN)GELS, but was it a rebus? That didn’t work with the across answer. What am I missing here? Then 52A reveals itself. Oh. I get it now! The only thing you had trouble parsing initially was (TR)IPLE A. It was my last fill and I’ve been a member since 1986 🤣. I also had cell instead of REEL for 14A which I knew was wrong and was easily corrected once the trick for the downs kicked in. Perfect trickery for a Thursday. Keep them coming, Jesse!
I had almost nothing for ten minutes! Hard, but doable and enjoyable once I got the gimmick, although I still had to get my bearings every now and then. Ended up taking a whopping 40:20.

Somewhere along the way, I figured out that the first two letters of the Down entries were missing.

But I didn't realize that the clues started with those same first two letters until I read the Gameplay. That would have helped.

A sneaky puzzle and I'm not sure if it's fair to a NEWBIE (54D) like me.

I feel like going on a Lewis Black style rant about this puzzle and how I can’t understand the people who are delighted with it. I couldn’t understand why the rebus wouldn’t accept my clearly correct answers. Even if the trick is that ______  then the rebus should be accepted. I’m actively skipping this half finished puzzle. Sorry but this is just a cruel motif.
Fastest Thursday ever!

A total non-starter for me. As very much a crossword beginner, I simply did not get enough across answers to ever solve any downs.

I got the gist fairly fast that the down answers were missing some letters, but just didn't get enough of the fill to figure out what.

Surprised by the hate for this puzzle! I thought it was a delight Utter confusion at first and then the moment it clicks and then the fun of solving the down entries once you know the trick. I was smiling as it all fell into place and that to me is good puzzle!

It’s days like these that I regret my “start with the down clues” strategy.

Fortunately, once I picked up the trick (roughly 80% of the way through the clues, given my strategy) it was easy enough!
Blown away by how clever this one was! At first I was annoyed, but once I got the trick, everything fell into place easily!
Loved the puzzle ! I solved but don’t understand Trip Lea. Anyone?

Without question my favourite NYT puzzle I’ve ever done. I was in despair with my first run through! But the theme clue changed my thinking. Once I got one the rest started tumbling in. The satisfaction from completing this with zero checks is incredible!!! Thanks Mr Goldberg - an absolute masterpiece

This is yet another puzzle where the across/down format is not accepted (e.g. “A/APP”) for bidirectional squares. I diligently filled out 37 bidirectional squares in that format to find this out.

When that didn’t work, I replaced them with the across letters only, which solved it, and then I realized that the last  bidirectional square to fill should not be “S/OUS” but “S/BES”. Which meant the entire test was inconclusive.

… so then I cleared the puzzle and retyped the entire thing, with all 37 correct bidirectional squares in the across/down format. It still didn’t work.

It would be nice if there was consistency for formatting!
Super fun theme! It’s not often I start out so completely stumped, then have such an aha moment when it all starts to make sense! Glad I stuck with it!
Very clever!  I filled it in pretty quickly once I figured out the revealer. Fun puzzle!

Two surprises after going through the comments:

1) The amount and intensity of the vitriol.

2) That most of the displeasure was not, "Cute, but WAY too easy for a Thursday."

Quick question, XWord-HiveMind:

Before I painstakingly rip out all the 3-letter "rebus-style" answers I entered for those top squares of all the down answers, before I rip those out and replace them with simply the last letter (the correct letter that makes the across answers work)-- before I go through all that, I have this format question: is my formatting accepted and maybe I just missed some unsuspected typo or incorrect answer, which is why no "Congratuulations!" page? DOES the puzzle accept *all 3 letters* for all those squares? Or will it only accept the *single letter* that makes the acrosses work, and THAT's why it's not giving me the "You did it!" page? I just don't wanna go through changing all those millions of down answers and then find that instead it was really just a typo I missed after all. (I deliberately haven't read the Wordplay column and have only skimmed through about 10 or 20 comments; don't wanna get any hints about any of the answers, just an answer to the formatting question). TIA. Anyone? Anyone? Bueller?

Great idea, I think?

It ew on me

I loved this one! I absolutely soared through it which is rarely the case for me on a Thursday. Very clever twist and rewarded a close reading of the clue. Also  made me happy I began with Across today.
From a technical standpoint, it was terrible that the app did not accept the "ST/A" format with the slash. That is the only format that lets you see both your across and down answers easily.
I'm too tired for this amount of thinking
Absolute waste of time. Enough of the trick puzzles already!

Jesse Goldberg, you are a genius.  My brain can't even compute what it takes to construct a puzzle like that. Bravo.   If I cared about streaks I might be miffed that it didn't accept the three letter answers I so painstakingly entered into each of the relevant squares but I don't so I'm not.
Urgh! I love Thursday puzzles and any time there’s a rebus, but there is seemingly no consensus for when you NEED to use a rebus and when you don’t.

Wow.  Reading the reactions today. I might solve a Thursday a third of the time at best.  And this was fun and easy for me.  But if I thought I needed to enter all those as a rebus, I would have hated for sure.

My personal ritual at the start of a puzzle is to go through the downs before hitting the acrosses, and boy did that do me no favours today! As I got to the bottom with far fewer entry points than normal, I seriously asked myself whether I got enough sleep last night!

Once I figured out the trick, it was smooth sailing and a lot of fun. And I immediately knew I'd be heading straight here after finishing, to write this message yes, but also to pull out the metaphorical popcorn as I fully expected a ton of salty responses. Folks did not fail me. 🍿
ry od zzle day!
This was one of those themes that just fell flat. Didn’t enjoy and suspect most people gave up.
Got it within half a dozen clues, then just a slog to the finish.  I appreciate the creativity but didn’t enjoy.
Didn't enjoy. I don't like these gimmicky puzzles. Quit after being stumped on all of the down clues.
Deb, I think you mean Jaw-  opping feeling!
As someone who relies a lot on the Down crossings, this was a struggle for me but I repect the cleverness.

The theme required  very little effort to work out, but the cutting off two letters was just headache-inducing rather than challenging. 

Also, I did not get the logic for the SETI clue. Is this a short form of a subject? I only know of the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, but that's more of an initiative than a subject.

Had to look up BEER HAT and still not sure what two letters can be added to MEO to get the curved part of jewelry.

Yeh the struggle was real on this one. Clever idea but strengthens my preference for solutions that are actual words in the grid. What can I say, I’m just a middling crossworder who likes a chill solve.
Figured that 52A was first few letters but was having trouble with the few part. Loved solving it.
I loved this puzzle. So much fun! Thank you for the much needed diversion!

The first time ever I realised what the trick was straight away, with 22D - ETHES for sees red. After that, many of the clues were fairly straightforward.

But, the 'American' clues were beyond me without crossers, like the Chicago Bulls clue, I didn't know 'threepeats' anyway; brands are pretty much impossible without being part of the trick! 

A couple of others, like BEER HAT, LIENEE and ERIE were unknown - but the Anaheim anGELS were in the crossword this week, weren't they?

My best ever Thursday.
Fun puzzle….took a while but then reka!

This was great. Lots  of fun, and I found challenges even after I cottoned ono the scheme, which is what kept me three minutes above my average.

Clung to Acer for 52A for way too long, and I found an unusual number of answers that I wasn't sure what they were even when I had them filled in.

In other words, an entirely appropriate Thursday.

Thanks!

One of the great Crosslandia moments is The Great Aha, the magnificent Riddlecrack.  

And sometimes, like today, it comes in the form of a rollercoaster moment, where you’ve been at the peak of struggle, like a rollercoaster slowly grinding up the huge hill, and then at the very top, where for a split second it sits still, the light bulb suddenly hits you, followed by the glorious and thrilling swoosh down.

Where you go from “Wha?” to “Whee!”, from clawing to soaring.  This puzzle was made for that, and you can see that it played out like that for many solvers, based on the comments. 

It sure did for me.  Makes me grateful to be enmeshed in our marvelous pastime that can create thrilling rushes like this out of a box of letters.

Kudos to Jesse for taking a game that Will Shortz devised for the 2025 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, and doing the remarkable grunt work of translating that idea into a flesh-and-blood puzzle.  Kudos to Jesse, who in his notes generously credits Will for the idea.  

Thank you, Jesse (and Will), for bringing thrill into the box today!

Might the gimmick have something to do with the edges?  Think again, X. Frustration #2.

OK, let's jump to the revealer and see if that helps things out.  But it takes a while to get enough crosses to figure it out.  Frustration #3.

OK, I've got it:  FIRST TWO LETTERS.  You mean *every* down answer is missing its FIRST TWO LETTERS???  That's gonna slow me down, but that's OK. I can do this.  Frustration #4.

A Modest Proposal

This amazing Thursday puzzle is behaving like a Thursday puzzle. It has a trick to solve. Many of us look forward to this. 

For those who feel otherwise, may I suggest a deal? We won't complain every Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday that the puzzles are too literal. We won't say 'so boring. Meh. What a slog. no tricks to solve.. don't make any more puzzles without a trick.' 

So you get 5 full days without hearing us complain. Can you reciprocate? If on the other 2 days, the constructor has managed an elegant, surprising experience, that gets different synapses firing while still tickling memory banks and logic circuits, can you try to appreciate the creativity and hard work? And recognize that people around the world are enjoying that moment of 'aha!!!'

Interesting puzzle, but it makes me rethink the meaning of a “gimme”. 1 across (onetime Mughal capital) was probably a gimme if you knew that AGRA was a Mughal capital (I didn’t, but I’m sure many did). But DELHI was also a onetime Mughal capital (apparently). But that’s 5 letters, so it wouldn’t fit….

Or could it? On a Thursday, you can’t really be sure of the number of letters in the answer (especially on this Thursday with regards to the down answers - until you figured out the trick).

The only real gimme is one that has only one possible answer. Or maybe one that you can be very, very sure of. But then if the crosses aren’t working, is it a gimme?  Maybe you’re missing something. 

Before figuring out the trick, I had RAT at 33 across (that ended up being correct). But 35 down “enter into a plot?” with 4 letters seemed very likely to be BURY - much more likely than the generic RAT. In a normal puzzle I would have thought BURY was a gimme. But today it wasn’t.
It took me longer than usual because I tried rebussing the first letters of each down clue.

Well, this was an emotional rollercoaster.
First across path - slim pickings, but let's keep going. 
52A - Oh, no. There's a trick with the downs.
First down pass - a couple of maybes. This is not going well.
I'm pretty sure about ANGELS - but what's missing? 
I think every AN might be missing. Nope. Maybe AN or EN.
STRAIGHTENUP saves the day. First two letters are always missing. Got it. 
Holy slog. Making some progress, but evaluating every possible combination of first two letters is --UGH. 
Holy smokes. Yellow star, just a couple of minutes above average, no lookups. Pretty pleased with myself. 
Read the column. 
THE FIRST TWO LETTERS WERE WHERE?
Feeling --UPID.
Worst puzzle ever.

It was 31D that clued me in to the theme: I had ADS, and thought, "AD SET? That doesn't make sense." But then I saw it! After that, filling in the rest of the puzzle was a breeze. For a while there I thought it was unsolvable.

I especially liked the bonus revealer: SKIM OFF THE TOP. Brilliant!

I was floored by this puzzle and literally gasped, because I saw that the first three down clues made actual words of their own (ARE, GEL, REAK) and I thought that this was an absolutely unreal feat of construction … to make every single down entry a word on its own minus the first two letters and have those words all properly cross with the acrosses. 

But no… the first three downs are just a happy coincidence I guess! The rest of the downs are NOT actual words on their own and this bugs me. Especially when the editors have rejected some of my own puzzles because “this is a rule” - but one I actually agree should be. 

Still a great puzzle! Props to the constructor. Just, oh, what could have been!…. *sigh*.

Ingenious and fun!

But when I didn't get the victory jingle it was really hard to troubleshoot.  It ended up that I had SCUSE/(PA)RESHES...

All of our operators a(REBUS)y. Where was I? Oh yeah - I was appropriately puzzled for quite a while, but finally tumbling to the trick was just a great 'aha' moment and a huge turning point. Just an amazing piece of construction and a tough but enjoyable workout. Two thumbs up. And an unrelated puzzle find today. This one was a bit different. A Thursday from May 4, 1989 by Betty Jorgensen. Three grid-spanning theme answers in that one. Here are the clues for those answers: "Start of a quip" "More of the quip" "End of the quip" And.. those answers: THEREISACHINESE POSTALSERVICEBY BOATITSJUNKMAIL Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=5/4/1989&g=54&d=A I'm done. ...

*"Green paint" is something that is an actual thing, but isn't a common phrase.

For example, "green thumb" is a common phrase but "yellow thumb" isn't.

Generally(but not alwaysly!), in crosswords, entries should be common words or phrases like greasepaint, oil paint, warpaint and finger paint, rather than random phrases like green paint and crossed-finger paint.

@Paul Anthony
About finding rebuses: you need to be very sure that your original answer is correct and /also/ too long for the allotted spaces. "This is a rebus," you will exclaim. 
You will then subtract number of answer squares from number of allotted squares and, after checking your arithmetic, you will conclude the answer's x letters too long. (You may talk to yourself a lot when rebus-ing.) That means you will have a square with x+1 letters jammed in. But which square?
Now you start checking cross-clues and you will find a sequence among them which doesn't make words with the letters in the rebus clues at the crossings. Aha!, you cry in triumph. There's the trouble, you will note, and start putting multiple letters in each square and looking for a set of crossings that makes sense, adjusting the other letters so they remain in line in their own answer sequences while fitting into the squishy rebus space.
Mostly, that should do it. But sometimes there may be more than one rebus in a clue or  (heavens!) more than one type of rebus in  a puzzle. Stay calm, breathe deep, keep trying.
Let us know how it goes.

@Ben Smith I fell this way after my first Thursday puzzle. But now I think this was a splendidly brilliant puzzle. If you want to enjoy these as well, you have to learn the unwritten rules of NYT. First is the rule of cool: if the construction is clever enough, it can break any or all the written rules. Second, Thursdays are not that hard, but there is a trick. There's almost always a revealer clue in puzzles like this, usually somewhere in the lower third, like today's.

@Tony Lewis

I swear to you on my life (which isn't all that impressive, but still...) that it is a matter of experience rather than knowledge or initial skill.

I've read that it is important to separate eggs which have male embryos from eggs with female embryos.  

The only problem is, no one knows how to tell the difference.  And yet, with feed back, many, many people have learned to tell the difference with incredible accuracy, although they don't have a clue as to how.

That's the way it is with Thursday puzzles.  There's a kind of buzz that your brain gives you when you're sure of something that doesn't fit.  

It begins as a tickle.  Then a little while later you get another tickle, another "why doesn't that work?".  By the time you get to the third tickle, you know something is up.  Now you're a predator with the scent.

Of course, part of the problem is to be able to solve enough of the puzzle to get the 3rd, 4th, etc. tickles:  that comes from everyday experience on crossword tricks like two things in a lifetime (LONGI) which give you the crosses. 

I can't describe it any better than that word salad.

But I can say it gets more fun.  I don't get them all, but the entertainment from those I do is well worth the price of admission, which is the frustration of those I don't.

@Mean Old Lady There is a book called Stumbling on Happiness....It begins with a thought experiment...How would you feel if you had to spend the rest of your life in a wheelchair....And overwhelmingly people will answer things like "i'd be miserable and wouldnt want to live like that".  except if you ask people in a wheelchair how they feel...They typically feel perfectly happy and have the same ups and downs as everyone else.

And then the book expands on that theme...given a restaurant and a good meal you had by surprise...would you want that meal every time or be surprised by a new meal every time?

And there we start getting to the core of the matter....Happiness really isnt as preprogrammed as we think it might be...Those things which surprise us tend to bring a greater degree of happiness than being fed the same thing we liked last time...

Its not the end point...its the little surprises along the journey which does it for people.
